text: Tesla turned a profit for the fourth straight quarter, making it eligible to join the S&P 500 stock index â€” and become part of the retirement accounts of millions of Americans. https://t.co/0VAd6elrBn

text:

name: NPR
text:
Idahoâ€™s coronavirus cases are rising exponentially, and about half of the more than 15,000 confirmed cases have come in the past two weeks.

"If we do not reverse this trend, we are headed for a crisis," says one hospital official. 
https://t.co/SHaztfT9pT

name: NPR
text:
Because of the pandemic, sports fans won't be in the stands this season. Instead, Major League Baseball is planning to pump recorded sounds of crowds into empty ballparks during games.
https://t.co/9fTldezFdR

name: NPR
text: The U.K. will no longer offer immunity to the family of U.S. staff at a military base where a diplomat's wife fled the country after allegedly killing a teenager with her car. https://t.co/IYYDuAG2jp

name: NPR
text:
The elderly and people with disabilities are already some of the most at-risk during natural disasters.

Amid an ongoing pandemic, officials across the South are scrambling to adjust their evacuation and shelter plans.  https://t.co/ODvQ2UrPKn

name: NPR
text:
The Florida Fish and Wildlife Conservation Commission approved a five-year ban on harvesting wild oysters from Apalachicola Bay to give the fishery time to recover.

Some oystermen worry closing the bay will be a final devastating blow.
https://t.co/HS428SOdhn

name: NPR
text:
President Trump says he will deploy federal agents to Chicago and Albuquerque, N.M., to fight what he says are "heinous crimes," adding that the administration has "no choice but to get involved."
https://t.co/AiuTEvTffh

name: NPR
text: An Arab-Muslim entrepreneur is facing a backlash and fighting to keep his once-burgeoning business alive after his daughter's racist and anti-LGBTQ social media posts became public. https://t.co/MjcO9hsSio

name: NPR
text: In 2018 Andrew Delke, a white Nashville police officer, shot Daniel Hambrick, a Black man, while he was running away with a gun. For the first time in the city's history, an officer was charged with murder. @WPLN's Deadly Force podcast digs into the case. https://t.co/3WLy6hs7UK

name: NPR
text: Nicholson Baker's "Baseless" misses the mark in an aim to take readers on a quest to discover if the U.S. used biological weapons developed in the '50s â€” and to examine the failings of public records law. https://t.co/YppyTPi8kK

name: NPR
text:
With peak hurricane season yet to come, southeast communities are grappling with whether it's possible to evacuate to shelters without risking coronavirus exposure.

"I'd stay outside before I'd go up in that school," says one Hurricane Katrina survivor.
https://t.co/HdjbxkGaKn

name: NPR
text:
The Seattle City Council supports a 50% cut to the police budget â€” a move the police chief says would be "reckless" right now.

â€œI'm hoping that people will calm down and look at ways that we can have a real plan in place," she says.

text: After a 25-year hiatus, Joshua Redman, Brad Mehldau, @jazznight host Christian McBride and Brian Blade reunite for a concert video â€” plus a Q&A about their new studio album.  https://t.co/qcyzUCqFi4

name: NPR
text: Anne Applebaum writes in "Twilight of Democracy" that heir to fears and hatreds, even advanced societies are straining under repeated blows: protracted war, economic disruptions, migration, a pandemic. https://t.co/zFFDfOJqHy

text: A college student's bill for outpatient knee surgery was a whopper â€” $96,377 â€” but the kicker was a $1,167 charge from a surgical assistant she didn't recall meeting or being told would be involved in her case. https://t.co/Jv3Pdq85oK

name: NPR
text:
In 2019, Gail Shepherd published a novel about a white girl growing up in the South. But in the original draft, the main character wasnâ€™t white; she was Vietnamese American.

name: NPR
text:
Kim Yo Jong has risen steadily in North Korean politics since her brother Kim Jong Un took power in 2011 â€” leading to speculation that she could one day become the country's first female leader.

But analysts say a patriarchal system makes that unlikely.

text:
